explanation:
For evaluating MISRA C string/buffer-bound rule violations you must inspect any callee that may perform memory/string operations on the 'userdigest' buffer or infer sizes from algorithm identifiers. Explaination for each symbol:

- digest_get_hash_size: The target compares userdigest_size to the value returned by this function. You must see its implementation/definition to confirm the mapping from algorithm (malgo3) to exact hash sizes and ensure the comparison enforces the same size used by downstream memcpy/memcmp calls.

- digest_auth_check_all: The target delegates authentication work to this function and passes (const uint8_t *)userdigest (but not userdigest_size). You must inspect its implementation to see whether it reads/writes userdigest and which size it uses (e.g., whether it recomputes hash size or assumes a different length), and whether it calls any <string.h> functions (memcpy/memcmp/etc.).

- digest_auth_check_all_inner: digest_auth_check_all calls this inner routine (per the call graph). The inner routine is a likely place for low-level buffer operations; inspect it for any string.h usages and the lengths/offsets it uses on the provided buffers.

- enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3 (definition) and enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 (definition): You need the enum definitions to know valid malgo3 values and how they encode/select the base algorithm(s). This determines which hash sizes should be used and which code paths in digest_get_hash_size or digest_auth_check_all may be taken.

- MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5, MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256, MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256: These macros define the bitmask bits tested in the target. Their exact values and semantics are required to verify the single-bit-check logic and to map malgo3 to the correct hash algorithm in the callee implementations.

- MHD_MD5_SUPPORT, MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT, MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT (preprocessor symbols): The target’s compiled behavior depends on which of these are defined. Which algorithm-specific code is present/absent affects which code paths remain and whether algorithm-not-supported branches (which return early) are compiled — that influences whether any string/buffer operations execute.

- MHD_DAUTH_WRONG_ALGO: The return code used when an unsupported algorithm is requested; useful to reason control-flow (early return) and ensure unsafe code paths are unreachable when this is returned.

- MHD_PANIC: The macro/function invoked on API violations (size mismatch or invalid malgo3). Knowing whether MHD_PANIC aborts/longjmp/returns (and whether it triggers __builtin_unreachable) matters to determine if subsequent code that might access buffers can be reached when the checks fail.

Provide the implementations/definitions of the above symbols (and the preprocessor configuration used to build the code) to the next agent so they can find any uses of memcpy/memcmp/memset/strlen/strcpy/etc., and verify that all invocations use lengths that are provably within the bounds of the referenced objects.
